facts.text: Sunderlal owned field No. 22 in Monza Umari, Taluq and District Akola, leased to Khushal Singh under registered lease for 5 years commencing April 1, 1954.
Field acquired by Government; Land Acquisition Officer awarded total compensation Rs. 26,105.58 on January 30, 1960, apportioned equally between Sunderlal and Khushal Singh.

On February 17, 1960, Land Acquisition Officer ordered amount for Khushal Singh kept in Revenue Deposit due to attachment order in C.S. No. 4-B/1958 by Civil Judge, Sr. Dn. Khamgaon; Sunderlal minor guardian objected.

Sunderlal filed application for reference under s.18 Land Acquisition Act claiming more compensation and that Khushal Singh not protected tenant post lease expiry; reference made June 27, 1961 as Land Acquisition Case No. 189/1961.
Khushal Singh applied for reference claiming enhancement and challenging apportionment; reference as Land Acquisition No. 190/1961.
On July 21, 1956, Sunderlal filed Civil Suit No. 133-B/1956 against Khushal Singh for rent due January 1, 1955 and 1956 in Civil Judge Akola.
Civil Court referred to Revenue Court under s.16A Berar Regulation of Agricultural Leases Act 1951 on July 22, 1957.
Sub-Divisional Officer Akola held July 25, 1958 (Revenue Case 79/1957-58) Khushal Singh not protected lessee.
Deputy Collector Akola on appeal held October 8, 1959 Khushal Singh protected lessee.
Bombay Revenue Tribunal confirmed Deputy Collector March 22, 1960.
Sunderlal filed Special Civil Application No. 232/1960 under Art. 226 Constitution.

Compromise petition Civil Application 163/1961 filed February 8, 1961 in SCA 232/1960; Khushal Singh agreed land leased for horticulture, not protected lessee, no objection to quashing revenue orders.

Paramsukhdas filed Civil Application 246/1961 March 11, 1961 claiming to be heard as decree holder against Khushal Singh, execution for Rs.20,013, attached Rs.13,644.27 compensation; alleged mala fide compromise.

Paramsukhdas withdrew attached amount Rs.13,644.27; filed Civil Application 365/61 April 18, 1961 stating not interested party but should be joined; advocate undertook to hold moneys subject to court orders.
High Court disposed applications August 3, 1961: parties file compromise in Civil Court under s.18 LA Act; kept proceedings pending; returned compromise petition to Sunderlal.
Sunderlal and Khushal Singh filed compromise applications September 18, 1961 in both LA references.
Paramsukhdas filed applications under O.XXII r.10 with s.151 CPC to be substituted/added as party, alleging fraudulent compromise.
Civil Judge rejected Paramsukhdas applications April 9, 1962; held not approached LAO, not person interested under s.20(b); reviewed July 6, 1962.

Paramsukhdas filed Civil Revisions 294/1962 and 295/1962 June 30, 1962; High Court allowed January 7, 1963, quashed orders, remitted to Civil Judge for fresh decision, allowed impleadment and amendments re compromise.
Sunderlal withdrew SCA 232/1960 August 22, 1962, dismissed September 24, 1962.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court had jurisdiction under s.115 CPC to interfere with Civil Judge's orders dated April 9, 1962.
Whether Paramsukhdas, an attaching creditor of Khushal Singh's share of compensation, is a 'person interested' entitled to be impleaded in s.18 references under Land Acquisition Act.
Whether revision lay or appeal against Civil Judge's orders.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court had no jurisdiction under s.115 CPC to interfere with Civil Judge's orders.
Paramsukhdas not a person interested in compensation, not entitled to impleadment under s.18 Land Acquisition Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.18, s.20(b) Land Acquisition Act; Manjoor Ahmad v. Rajlaxmi Dasi; Abu Bakar v. Peary Mohan Mukherjee

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal lay to High Court, not revision.
Even if impleaded, Paramsukhdas cannot challenge compromise between Sunderlal and Khushal Singh as beyond scope of s.18 reference.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.18, s.20, s.21 Land Acquisition Act

respondent_arguments.text: Paramsukhdas is person interested in objection under s.20 and affected by objection under s.21 Land Acquisition Act as attaching creditor.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3(b), s.20, s.21 Land Acquisition Act; O.XXII r.10 CPC via s.53 Land Acquisition Act

court_reasoning.text: Paramsukhdas claims interest in compensation, falls within inclusive definition s.3(b) Land Acquisition Act; entitled to be heard under ss.20,21 if interest affected by objections on amount/apportionment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Person claiming interest in compensation is 'person interested'; scheme of Act safeguards such interests post-acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held orders of April 9, 1962 not 'awards' under s.54 Land Acquisition Act; revision maintainable.
Paramsukhdas entitled to raise all points to protect interests affected by objections, including challenging compromise; no bar under s.21.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Interest of justice requires single proceeding.

holdings.text: Attaching creditor claiming interest in compensation is 'person interested' under s.3(b), entitled to impleadment in s.18 reference if affected by objections under ss.20,21 Land Acquisition Act.
High Court had jurisdiction in revision; orders not appealable as not awards.

precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of s.18 reference limited; party not seeking reference cannot indirectly challenge via another's reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abu Bakar v. Peary Mohan Mukherjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Court limited to referred objections; distinguished as Paramsukhdas not party before Collector who failed to seek reference.
Person acquiring right to compensation post-award can prosecute reference; supports devolution of title including to attaching creditor.

precedents_cited.case_name: Promotha Nath Mitra v. Rakshal Das Addy
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchaser post-award at auction can prosecute s.30 reference.
Attaching creditor directed to be made party to reference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Siva Pratapa Bhattadu v. A.E.L. Mission
precedents_cited.relevance: Attaching creditor is person interested under s.3(b).

precedents_cited.case_name: Gobinda Kumar Roy Chowdhury v. Debendra Kumar Roy Chowdhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar to Abu Bakar; party failing to seek reference cannot join another's.

precedents_cited.case_name: Karuna Sindhu Dhar v. Panna Lal Paramanik
precedents_cited.relevance: Cannot vary award for party not claiming full before Collector.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'person interested'; governs references, objections, apportionment, impleadment; court interprets to include claimants to compensation.

statutes_cited.name: Berar Regulation of Agricultural Leases Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Prior litigation on protected tenancy status.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision jurisdiction; substitution/impleadment applied via s.53 LA Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court judgment allowing civil revisions, quashing Civil Judge's orders refusing impleadment, remitting for fresh decision with Paramsukhdas impleaded and liberty to amend pleadings re compromise.
outcome.relief_granted: Paramsukhdas allowed to be impleaded as party; matter remitted to Civil Judge Akola for fresh merits decision.

key_quotes.text: "the expression person interested includes all persons claiming an interest in compensation to be made on account of the acquisition of land under this Act"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Inclusive definition under s.3(b) LA Act covers Paramsukhdas.

key_quotes.text: Paramsukhdas was clearly a person interested in the objections which were pending before the Court in the references made to it and that he was also a person whose interest would be affected by the objections, within s. 21.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on entitlement to impleadment.

key_quotes.text: "It would be strange to come to the conclusion that the Legislature is keen that a person claiming an interest in compensation should be heard before the land is acquired but is not interested in him after the land is acquired."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains scheme of LA Act safeguarding compensation claimants.
